text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 10.2.5, Identiﬁcation Media.
This IRM was updated to reﬂect current organizational titles, scope, deﬁnitions, responsibilities, and authorized use.
The following sections have been updated/clariﬁed with this version of policy: a. IRM
, Responsibilities: Added reporting requirement for separating employees, and monitoring training completion for contractor employees. b. IRM
, Responsibilities and IRM
, Replacement ID Cards: Added Interim Guidance Memorandum FMSS-
, Interim Guidance on FMSS Physical Security Lost, Stolen, or Compromised ID Media for IRM
, Identiﬁcation Media dated
c. IRM
, Mailing of ID Media: Added requirement to provide tracking number. d. IRM
, Photo ID Cards: Added requirement to submit ﬁnal staff-like access memorandum. e. IRM
, Replacement ID Cards: Removed TIGTA reporting requirement. f. IRM
, Vehicle ID Media: Updated section name from Parking Permits to Vehicle ID media. Added new policy and procedures for Vehicle ID media issuance. g. IRM
, Recovery of ID Media: Updated procedures for recovering ID Media for employees/contractor employees placed in non-work status. h. IRM
, Records and Accountability: Added new procedures for recoverable and non-recoverable ID Media.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This IRM incorporates Interim Guidance Memorandum FMSS-10-1220-0007, Interim Guidance on FMSS Physical Security Lost, Stolen, or Compromised ID Media for IRM 10.2.5, Identiﬁcation Media dated December 2, 2020.
AUDIENCE
Table of Contents

) This section applies to the control, issuance, and disposition of (ID) media. ID media are authorized forms of ID that are designed to evidence of the bearer’s identity, authorization to access IRS facilities or systems, or authority to act as an agent of the IRS in the performance of official duties. (

) Purpose: This IRM provides an overview of the authorized forms of ID issued by the IRS to employees and contractor employees, and establishes the policies for the control, issuance, and recovery of ID media. (
) Audience: All IRS Organizations. (
) Policy Owner: Chief, FMSS. (
) Program Owner: FMSS, Associate Director (AD), Security. (
) Primary Stakeholders: FMSS, Field Operations. (

) Program Goals: To affirm IRS authorized ID media and establish the processes and procedures for the issuance, maintenance, and recovery of media to mitigate unauthorized access to IRS systems and facilities, and to protect IRS personnel, assets, and information. (

) IRS ID media is issued solely for use by authorized IRS employees and tractor employees, other Federal agency employees and contractors, in the performance of official duties, and visitors (official or unofficial). (
) Office of Management and Budget (OMB) M-
: Implementation of land Security Presidential Directive (HSPD)
- Policy for a Common cation Standard for Federal Employees and Contractors (
) Federal Information Processing Standards (FIPS)
, Personal Identity cation (PIV) of Federal Employees and Contractors (
United States Code (USC)
: Military, naval, or official passes (
USC
: Official badges, identiﬁcation cards, other insignia (
) HSPD-
- Policy for a Common Identiﬁcation Standard for Federal and Contractors (
) The Chief, FMSS, is authorized to prescribe ID media for use within the per Delegation Order
, Authorization to Perform Functions of the sioner, located in IRM
, Servicewide Policies and Authorities, Delegations of Authority. (
) The AD, Security, is responsible for oversight of ID media for use within the IRS. (
) The Chief, Access & Identiﬁcation Management (AIM), is responsible for oversight of the planning, developing, implementing, evaluating, and the ID Media Program. (
) The Chief, Identity Credential and Access Management (ICAM), is for planning, developing, implementing, evaluating, and controlling the ID Media Program. Internal Revenue Manual

IRS ID media is issued solely for use by authorized IRS employees and tractor employees, other Federal agency employees and contractors, in the performance of official duties, and visitors (official or unofficial).
Federal Information Processing Standards (FIPS) 201, Personal Identity Veriﬁ- cation (PIV) of Federal Employees and Contractors
Physical Security (

) FMSS Territory Managers (TM) are responsible for ensuring FMSS Security Section Chief(s) (SSC) follow IRS policy and provide oversight in the imple- mentation and enforcement of the ID Media Program. (
) FMSS SSC are responsible for implementing and enforcing the ID Media Program within their assigned territory, ensuring that IRS policy and proce- dures are followed. (

) All IRS managers, Contracting Officer’s Representatives (COR), and ment Officials with personnel administrative functions have a responsibility a. Informing all employees in their span of control of the importance of following ID media practices. b. Verifying only authorized personnel are in the work area for which are responsible and immediately challenging and/or reporting the presence of suspected unauthorized persons in a work area. c. Ensuring that authorized employees in their span of control are issued the appropriate ID media, use, and display their ID media at all times. d. Recovering ID media of employees and contractor employees who separate or are placed in non-work status on their last workday and mediately sending the recovered ID media to the local FMSS physical security office for disposition or retention. e. Reporting unrecovered ID media of employees and contractor who separate or are placed in non-work status to the local FMSS physical security office, the Situational Awareness Management (SAMC), and Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration in accordance with IRM

, Physical Security Program, Incident Reporting. f. Certifying the disposition of issued ID media items to include the recovered ID media items to the local FMSS physical security office, using the automated Human Resources (HR) Connect Separating Employee Clearance (SEC) module for employees, and attaching

, Contractor Separation Checklist to the Separating Contractor Clearance (SCC) module for contractor employees. g. Completing a request for a replacement ID media for their employees and contractor employees when ID media:
Is worn or damaged.
Is reported lost or stolen.
No longer accurately depicts the bearer.
Is not displaying accurate legal or pseudonym name.
Is no longer required with designator. h. Ensuring staff-like access eligibility requirements are met, as per IRM
, Physical Security Program, Physical Access Control (PAC). i. Ensuring all contractor employees in their span of control complete Security Awareness Training timely in accordance with IRM
, Personnel Security, Contractor Investigations, and ensuring it is docu- mented in Integrated Talent Management (ITM). (

) All employees and other persons issued ID media are responsible for: a. Safeguarding their ID media. b. Displaying their ID media properly at all times when present at an IRS facility and/or performing work duties. c. Promptly reporting loss of their ID media to their manager. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
H

IRS managers, Contracting Officer’s Representatives (COR), and Govern- Officials with personnel administrative functions have a responsibility for: a. Informing all employees in their span of control of the importance of following ID media practices. b. Verifying only authorized personnel are in the work area for which they are responsible and immediately challenging and/or reporting the presence of suspected unauthorized persons in a work area. c. Ensuring that authorized employees in their span of control are issued the appropriate ID media, use, and display their ID media at all times. d. Recovering ID media of employees and contractor employees who separate or are placed in non-work status on their last workday and im- mediately sending the recovered ID media to the local FMSS physical security office for disposition or retention. e. Reporting unrecovered ID media of employees and contractor employees who separate or are placed in non-work status to the local FMSS physical security office, the Situational Awareness Management Center (SAMC), and Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) in accordance with IRM

, Physical Security Program, Incident Reporting. f. Certifying the disposition of issued ID media items to include the return of recovered ID media items to the local FMSS physical security office, using the automated Human Resources (HR) Connect Separating Employee Clearance (SEC) module for employees, and attaching Form

, Contractor Separation Checklist to the Separating Contractor Clearance (SCC) module for contractor employees. g. Completing a request for a replacement ID media for their employees and contractor employees when ID media:
Is worn or damaged.
Is reported lost or stolen.
No longer accurately depicts the bearer.
All IRS managers, Contracting Officer’s Representatives (COR), and Govern- ment Officials with personnel administrative functions have a responsibility for:
Safeguarding their ID media. Displaying their ID media properly at all times when present at an IRS facility and/or performing work duties. Promptly reporting loss of their ID media to their manager.

d. Presenting their ID media when requested by their manager, the the local FMSS physical security office to allow for IRS accountability such ID media. e. Returning their ID media to their manager/COR when placed in a work status or upon separation from the IRS. f. Reporting lost or stolen ID media immediately to their manager, the FMSS physical security office, and to SAMC in accordance with IRM
, Physical Security Program, Incident Reporting. (
) Program Reports: a. HRConnect Personal Identity Veriﬁcation (PIV) Data Synchronization b. USAccess Applicant Status Report (
) Program Effectiveness: a. Timely revocation of physical access b. Recovery of all ID media from unauthorized persons c. Timely completion of all Smar
D card maintenance requirements d. Issuance of ID media only to authorized personnel (
) Annual Review: ICAM conducts annual reviews to assess all processes program and ensures the program operates in compliance with laws and lations of the Department of the Treasury (“Treasury”). (

) Access - The permissions granted to employees and contractor that provide opportunity to physically come into contact with (including, but limited to reading, transporting, and/or transcribing/interpreting) Sensitive Unclassiﬁed (SBU) data in the performance of official duties, entering an controlled facility or space, and/or to login to IRS systems with approved dentials. Note: For additional information related to facility access, see IRM

Presenting their ID media when requested by their manager, the COR, or the local FMSS physical security office to allow for IRS accountability of such ID media. Returning their ID media to their manager/COR when placed in a non- work status or upon separation from the IRS. Reporting lost or stolen ID media immediately to their manager, the local FMSS physical security office, and to SAMC in accordance with IRM
, Physical Security Program, Incident Reporting.
(04-28-2021) Program Management and Review
For additional information related to facility access, see IRM Physical Security Program, Physical Access Control.
Contracting Officer’s Representative (COR)

An individual designated and authorized by the Contracting Officer (CO) to perform contract administration activities on his/her behalf within the limits of delegated authority for a speciﬁc acquisition or contract.
Contractor employee - An individual, not a federal employee, who work for or on behalf of the Federal Government.
Note: For additional information, see IRM 10.23.2, Personnel Security, Contractor Investigations.
Escorted Access - Access given to an individual (such as a contractor employee, visitor, or vendor) who is not approved for staff-like access
must be accompanied by a ″qualiﬁed escort″ during work performance entry and movement throughout the facility. Note: For additional information related to escorted access, see IRM
, Physical Security Program, Physical Access Control (PAC). (
) ID Card - A form of ID media that veriﬁes the identity of the bearer through identiﬁable data, which may include the bearer’s photograph, name, agency affiliation, and card number. (

) ID Card Designations - Symbols that appear on ID cards that indicate a speciﬁed privilege or level of physical access, including concealed weapon, limited area, or federal emergency response official. (

) ID Media - IRS ID media includes any pass, badge, credential, photo or photo ID card, pocket commission, or similar items, which contain the IRS name, seal, or symbol, that is normally issued to and displayed by the ID media may also contain one or more of the following: a. The bearer’s photograph. b. A serial number. c. An authorizing or validating signature. d. Information indicating the purpose of the media or indicating the has been officially authorized to perform certain acts or duties. Insignia - A badge, usually attached to an article of clothing, which the bearer’s affiliation with the IRS. Logical Access - Access to IRS information systems or to Information nology (IT) resources. Non-Work Status - An IRS employee in a temporary non-pay status as a seasonal or intermittent worker, or on extended Leave Without Pay (LWOP), extended Absence Without Leave (AWOL), furlough, suspension, or other pay status. Physical Access Control (PAC) Card - A photo ID card issued in with HSPD-

that veriﬁes the identity of the bearer for facility access. Pseudonyms - A pseudonym is a ﬁctitious name. The use of a pseudonym issued to IRS employees for the protection of personal safety and the tion of harm or danger. Note: For additional information, see IRM

, Privacy and Information tion, Use of Pseudonyms by IRS Employees. Qualiﬁed Escort - An authorized (designated) IRS employee or a employee approved for ﬁnal staff-like access at the same or higher position risk level as the individual who requires escorting, and with knowledge of task or activity to be performed. Note: For additional information on qualiﬁed escorts, see IRM

, Physical Security Program, Physical Access Control. Recovered - A classiﬁcation for ID media returned to the manager or COR forwarded to the local FMSS physical security office for ﬁnal disposition. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
H
must be accompanied by a ″qualiﬁed escort″ during work performance and/or entry and movement throughout the facility.
Note: For additional information related to escorted access, see IRM 10.2.18, Physical Security Program, Physical Access Control (PAC).
Physical Access Control (PAC) Card - A photo ID card issued in accordance with HSPD-12 that veriﬁes the identity of the bearer for facility access.
Note: For additional information, see IRM 10.5.7, Privacy and Information Protec- tion, Use of Pseudonyms by IRS Employees.
Qualiﬁed Escort
An authorized (designated) IRS employee or a contractor employee approved for ﬁnal staff
like access at the same or higher position risk level as the individual who requires escorting, and with knowledge of the task or activity to be performed.
Recovered - A classiﬁcation for ID media returned to the manager or COR and forwarded to the local FMSS physical security office for ﬁnal disposition.
Media
) Routine Access - Access to facilities on a consistent basis, generally times per week. (
) Smar
D - An ID card issued in accordance with HSPD-
that veriﬁes the identity of the bearer through visible and embedded biometric data. The Smar
D card provides logical and physical access. (

) Staff-like Access - Unescorted access to Treasury-owned or controlled ties, information systems, security items and products, and/or to areas or processing SBU data, as determined by Treasury/bureau officials. access is initially granted on an interim basis; ﬁnal access granted once full background investigation has been completed. Note: For additional information, see IRM
, Personnel Security, Investigations. (

) Unescorted Access - Access without escort to IRS facilities, IT systems, SBU data. Unescorted access is granted to all IRS employees, and to tor employees who are granted staff-like access. Unescorted access is an element of staff-like access authorization. Note: For additional information regarding unescorted access, see IRM
, Physical Security Program, Physical Access Control. (

) Vehicle ID Media - Vehicle ID media includes any pass, sticker, decal, or similar items, which authorize individuals to enter IRS parking garages, and other designated structures with their vehicle. Vehicle ID media may contain one or more of the following: a. License plate number b. A serial number c. Permit number d. Information that indicates the purpose of the media or the bearer has been officially authorized for vehicular access. Note: Vehicle ID media applies to Facility Security Level (FSL) III through IV ties. For additional information, see IRM
, Physical Security Basic Physical Security Concepts. (

) Visitor - A person visiting an IRS facility who has not been issued an IRS photo ID card. Visitors may include contractor employees who have or have not been approved for staff-like access, other federal agency employees contractors, and the general public. (
) Unrecoverable - A classiﬁcation for ID media not returned to the manager COR after reasonable attempts have been made for its return. (
) Acronyms Acronym Deﬁnition AD Associate Director AIM Access and ID Management AWOL Absence Without Leave Internal Revenue Manual

that veriﬁes the identity of the bearer through visible and embedded biometric data. The Smar
D card provides logical and physical access. (

) Staff-like Access - Unescorted access to Treasury-owned or controlled ties, information systems, security items and products, and/or to areas or processing SBU data, as determined by Treasury/bureau officials. access is initially granted on an interim basis; ﬁnal access granted once full background investigation has been completed.

Staff-like Access - Unescorted access to Treasury-owned or controlled facili- ties, information systems, security items and products, and/or to areas storing or processing SBU data, as determined by Treasury/bureau officials. Staff-like access is initially granted on an interim basis; ﬁnal access granted once full
Unescorted Access
Access without escort to IRS facilities, IT systems, and SBU data. Unescorted access is granted to all IRS employees, and to tor employees who are granted staff
like access. Unescorted access is an element of staff
like access authorization.
Note: For additional information regarding unescorted access, see IRM 10.2.18, Physical Security Program, Physical Access Control.
Vehicle ID Media

Vehicle ID media includes any pass, sticker, decal, permit, or similar items, which authorize individuals to enter IRS parking garages, lots, and other designated structures with their vehicle. Vehicle ID media may also contain one or more of the following:
Unrecoverable - A classiﬁcation for ID media not returned to the manager or COR after reasonable attempts have been made for its return.

IRM 1.22.3, Mail and Transportation Management, Addressing and Packaging
Physical Security (

) Only ID media issued in accordance with, or as referenced in, this IRM are authorized for use by IRS employees and contractor employees during performance of official duties. The issuance and use of pocket commissions covered in IRM
, Physical Security Program, Civil Enforcement and Enforcement Pocket Commissions, and enforcement badges in IRM
, Fiscal and Personnel Matters, Investigative Property. (

) IRS employees and contractor employees must take precautions to prevent loss, theft, or destruction of pocket commissions, ID cards, and enforcement badges. In the hands of an unauthorized person, these ID media items have the potential of bringing serious discredit and adverse publicity to the IRS. employees and contractor employees are responsible for safeguarding their media on their person or in a locked container. ID media must never be left unattended in briefcases, unlocked desk drawers, automobiles, etc. (

) No IRS employee or contractor employee may possess more than one IRS card. No IRS employee or contractor employee may be issued more than of each type of authorized ID media at any given time, including ID card, pocket commission, and enforcement badge, unless otherwise authorized by the AD, Security. (
) IRS employees and contractor employees must return all ID media when separate or terminate employment (resignation or retirement, transferring to another federal agency, removal, etc.). (
) IRS employees and contractor employees must never copy or photograph ID media, nor allow anyone to copy or photograph their ID media, as per
USC
) ID media may not be used for retirement mementos, honorary presentations, or similar purposes, except as prescribed in IRM
, Physical Security Program, Civil Enforcement and Non-Enforcement Pocket Commissions and IRM
, Fiscal and Personnel Matters, Investigative Property. (
) See
USC
: Military, naval, or official passes (
) See
USC
: Official badges, identiﬁcation cards, other insignia (

) ID media may be mailed when an ID card must be: a. Transferred to another credentialing station, including non-IRS ing stations, or to a Light Activation Kit (LAK) station. b. Returned to the local FMSS physical security office due to employee or contractor employee separation or placement in a non-work status. (
) When mailing ID media, a controlled means must be used. The mailing package must be accompanied by a Form
, Document Transmittal, including the name of the package recipient, date sent, serial number, type ID media, quantity of blank stock (if applicable) and cardholder’s name (if plicable). Form
must be retained for use in ensuring the timely receipt the transmitted items. The recipient must return the signed Form
ing receipt. A copy of the signed Form
, signifying receipt of the documents, must be retained in the local FMSS physical security office. (
) When ID media must be mailed: Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
H
IRS employees and contractor employees must never copy or photograph their ID media, nor allow anyone to copy or photograph their ID media, as per 18
a. Use a sealed envelope with the name of the receiving employee or con

tractor employee recorded on the face of the envelope. The sealed envelope containing the ID media must then be enclosed in an or package prepared for mailing. b. Use traceable means such as the United States Postal Service (USPS) registered mail or by a traceable means with a tracking number. The tracking number must be sent to the package recipient once it is from the mailing service.
Note: For additional information, see IRM 1.22.3, Mail and Transportation Manage- ment, Addressing and Packaging.

The authorized forms of ID media approved for use by IRS employees, tractor employees, and visitors are as follows: a. ID cards (photo and non-photo). b. Non-enforcement Pocket Commissions, as per IRM
, Physical Security Program, Civil Enforcement and Non-Enforcement Pocket missions. c. Enforcement Pocket Commissions as per IRM

, Fiscal and Personnel Matters, Investigative Property d. Parking permits to IRS controlled parking areas. e. Insignia provided to IRS personnel for attachment to issued apparel. IRS employees, contractor employees, and visitors may not display any of ID media associating them with the IRS except as referenced in this unless otherwise officially authorized by the Chief, FMSS. Requests for the development of new, or modiﬁcation of existing ID and/or the method of use, assembly, or display, must be submitted Operating Business Commissioner, Chief Officer, or Chief Counsel of the questing organization to the FMSS AD, Security, for coordination and The Chief, FMSS is the approving authority for any amendments to any IRS ID media, unless otherwise indicated in this IRM. All other forms of ID media not speciﬁcally covered in this IRM, IRM Physical Security Program, Civil Enforcement and Non-Enforcement Commissions, or IRM

, Fiscal and Personnel Matters, Investigative Property are not authorized. ID cards (including, but not limited to photo and non-photo ID cards) are to verify the bearer’s identity and/or to designate their type of authorized access. Photo ID cards are only issued by the local FMSS physical security office employees and contractor employees who meet the eligibility staff-like access, as per IRM
, Physical Security Program, Physical Access Control (PAC), IRM
, Personnel Security, Contractor tions, and require physical and/or logical access to IRS facilities and Authorized photo ID cards are the Smar
D and PAC cards.
The authorized forms of ID media approved for use by IRS employees, con- tractor employees, and visitors are as follows:
ID cards (photo and non-photo). Non-enforcement Pocket Commissions, as per IRM
, Physical Security Program, Civil Enforcement and Non-Enforcement Pocket missions. Enforcement Pocket Commissions as per IRM
, Fiscal and Personnel Matters, Investigative Property Parking permits to IRS controlled parking areas. Insignia provided to IRS personnel for attachment to issued apparel.
ID cards (including, but not limited to photo and non-photo ID cards) are used to verify the bearer’s identity and/or to designate their type of authorized
Authorized photo ID cards are the SmartID and PAC cards.
(NTEU) Chapter Presidents who meet the eligibility requirements for access. (

) PAC cards may be issued to individuals who meet the eligibility requirements for staff-like access and only require routine access to IRS controlled Note: PAC cards are used for physical access only and are normally designed to be temporary in nature. (
) Employees must complete and submit Form
, Request for ID Media for IRS Employees prior to the issuance of a photo ID card. (
) Contractor employees must complete and submit Form

-A, Request for ID Media for Non-IRS Employees and provide a copy of their current access memorandum issued by Human Capital Officer (HCO) Personnel Security prior to the issuance of a photo ID card. Final staff-like access randums issued to contractor employees after card issuance must be forwarded to the local FMSS physical security office. (

) Personnel that require photo ID cards are required to have a photograph to provide an immediate visual veriﬁcation of the bearer’s identity. Personnel must provide a neutral facial expression for the photo, where all facial are in a relaxed state. Wearing hats, scarves, caps, or items that may the facial features are prohibited unless worn for reasons of religion or Exceptions must be approved by the employee’s manager or COR and the local FMSS SSC and notated in the employee’s USAccess record. (

) All personnel must ensure ID cards are in their possession when conducting official business. ID cards must be worn at or above the waist and displayed visibly from the front when in IRS facilities. Smar
D cards must be carried in an IRS issued holder to safeguard the ID card certiﬁcate. When the Smar

D card is being utilized for work processes, such as Enterprise Single Sign-On Logon Manager (ESSO-LM), it is allowable to not have the card displayed as long as it is in the cardholder’s physical possession at all times. Authorized IRS personnel visiting an IRS facility on official business must display their issued ID card. Authorized IRS visitors requiring access to Areas must display a photo or non-photo ID card with a “Limited Area” desig- nation.
PAC cards may be issued to individuals who meet the eligibility requirements for staff-like access and only require routine access to IRS controlled
Employees must complete and submit Form 13716, Request for ID Media IRS Employees prior to the issuance of a photo ID card.
page Note: For additional information, see IRM
, Physical Security Program, Physical Access Control (PAC). (
) Employees with an approved pseudonym, as prescribed in IRM
, and Information Protection, Use of Pseudonyms by IRS Employees must be issued a Smar

D or PAC card in their pseudonym name only. Previously issued ID cards must be recovered and returned to the local FMSS physical security office prior to the issuance of a new ID card. The pseudonym name must match on the Smar
D card and the enforcement or non-enforcement pocket commission, if applicable. (

) Employees and contractor employees must request a replacement card if a. Current ID card has expired (ID cards must be updated every ﬁve b. ID card is lost (a wait of ﬁve to seven business days is usually ate to ensure a card is lost and not merely misplaced). c. ID card is stolen. d. Cardholder’s name has changed. e. ID card is damaged. f. Image of the cardholder no longer accurately depicts the cardholder. (
) Cardholders must immediately report lost, stolen, or compromised ID cards a. Their manager or COR b. The local FMSS physical security office by submitting Form
, Lost Forgotten Identiﬁcation (ID) Media Record c. SAMC in accordance with IRM
, Physical Security Program, Incident Reporting (
) IRS employees who require a replacement ID card must complete and Form
, Request for ID Media for IRS Employees to the local FMSS physical security office to obtain a replacement ID card. (
) Contractor employees who require a replacement ID card must complete submit Form

-A, Request for ID Media for Non-IRS Employees and a copy of their current staff-like access memorandum issued by HCO, Security to the local FMSS physical security office to obtain a replacement card. (

) Local physical security offices must complete revocation procedures within hours of notiﬁcation of lost, stolen, or compromised cards. In emergency tions where there is suspicion the missing ID card could be misused, the FMSS physical security office must take immediate action to disseminate information to SAMC and TIGTA to prevent unauthorized access to IRS ties and systems. (
) Non-photo ID cards are issued by the local FMSS physical security office a. Visitors who meet the eligibility requirements for staff-like access, as IRM

, Physical Security Program, Physical Access Control b. Visitors who do not meet the eligibility requirements for staff-like c. Individuals who are not granted unescorted entry authorization within Limited Areas, as per IRM
, Physical Security Program, Access Control (PAC).
Employees with an approved pseudonym, as prescribed in IRM
, and Information Protection, Use of Pseudonyms by IRS Employees must be issued a Smar

D or PAC card in their pseudonym name only. Previously issued ID cards must be recovered and returned to the local FMSS physical security office prior to the issuance of a new ID card. The pseudonym name must match on the Smar
D card and the enforcement or non-enforcement pocket commission, if applicable.
Visitors who meet the eligibility requirements for staff-like access, as per IRM

, Physical Security Program, Physical Access Control (PAC). Visitors who do not meet the eligibility requirements for staff-like access. Individuals who are not granted unescorted entry authorization within Limited Areas, as per IRM
, Physical Security Program, Physical Access Control (PAC).

d. Employees/contractor employees reporting to IRS facilities without photo ID card. Note: Non-photo ID cards to designated limited areas are issued by designated Business Unit limited area monitors. (

) The authorized non-photo ID cards are Visitor, Visitor Escort Only, Visitor Limited Area, and Temporary ID cards. Individuals who require non-photo ID cards must have ID designations on the front of the ID card. The ID tions are as follows: a. “V” in a red ﬁeld – Visitor b. “E” in a red ﬁeld – Visitor Escort Only c. “R” in a yellow ﬁeld – Visitor Limited Area d. “T” in a blue ﬁeld – Temporary (
) Visitors and federal or non-federal personnel who have met the eligibility re- quirements for staff-like access as set forth in IRM
, Physical Program, Physical Access Control (PAC) must be issued non-photo “Visitor” cards by the local FMSS physical security office for unescorted access. (

) Visitors who have not met the eligibility requirements must: a. Be escorted by an IRS employee, who must request his/her placement on the facility visitor access list. b. Present a government or state issued photo ID card for identity tion and submit to facility entry screening procedures. c. Be issued a non-photo “Visitor Escort Only” ID card. (
) Visitors who have not been granted unescorted entry authorization within Limited Areas as set forth in IRM

must: a. Be placed on the Limited Area Register by the Business Unit limited monitor. b. Be escorted by an IRS employee. c. Present a government or state issued photo ID card for identity tion and submit to Limited Area screening procedures. d. Be issued a non-photo “Visitor Limited Area” ID card. (
) Employees/contractor employees who report to IRS facilities without their issued photo ID card must complete and submit Form
, Lost or Identiﬁcation (ID) Media Record to the local FMSS physical security office must be issued a “Temporary” ID card. (

) Non-photo ID cards cannot be removed from the issuing facility and should never be used as access authorization to a facility. Non-photo ID cards must be returned to local FMSS physical security office or guard post by the indi- vidual assigned the card when the individual departs the facility or security area. (
) Contractor employees who have been denied ﬁnal staff-like access by HCO Personnel Security cannot be allowed entry or escorted. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) Employees and authorized contractor employees requiring routine access an IRS controlled facility or space (government owned or leased) with an tronic access control system may be issued a proxy/access card, where required. (

) Proxy/access cards are non-photo, electronic cards that work with the control system to unlock a door or a similar structure, replacing a key and lock. Proxy/access cards further restrict access to an area and an alternate method to provide access when coding of the Smar
D or PAC not practical. (
) Employees who require a proxy/access card must complete and submit
, Request for ID Media for IRS Employees to the local FMSS security office to obtain a proxy/access card. (
) Contractor employees who require a proxy/access card must complete and submit Form
-A, Request for ID Media for Non-IRS Employees and a copy of their current staff-like access memorandum issued by HCO, Security, to the local FMSS physical security office to obtain a card. (

) Proxy/access cards must be issued by the local FMSS physical security for applicable IRS controlled facilities or space. Proxy/access cards must returned to the local FMSS physical security office upon separation or non- work status by the individual assigned the card or their manager. Note: access cards are not transferable. (
) The local FMSS TM has authority to designate the locations where vehicle media is used and the procedures for issuance and control. (
) The local FMSS physical security office is responsible for development, mentation, maintenance, and control of the vehicle ID media. (

Note: Vehicle ID media are not transferable.
Vehicle ID media are not authorized for personnel who are also receiving compensation through the Public Transportation Subsidy Program

Vehicle ID media must be placed so that it can be readily seen by the guard. The SSC determines the placement of the vehicle ID media, which may be on either rear side windows, front or rear windows, or any other prominent location that is compliant with state and local laws.

) If the vehicle ID media for an employee/contractor employee vehicle is a parking permit (ID stickers or decals) not permanently affixed to the vehicle, the media must contain a serial number and the employee must show their IRS photo ID to gain access. (

a. Authorized individuals (e.g., employee or program manager) must an access request to the local FMSS physical security office. b. a. Authorized individuals (e.g., COR or manager) must submit an access request to the local FMSS physical security office. b. ) Concurrent with the issuance of vehicle ID media, the employee must be informed of the requirement to remove and return the media or remains to local FMSS physical security office prior to selling or trading the vehicle, or if that area on the vehicle where the media is affixed is damaged and In addition, the local FMSS physical security office must be informed when vehicle ID media is destroyed, lost, or stolen. (

) For vehicle ID media mass re-issue, color scheme and designation should varied each time the identiﬁers are changed. The decision to conduct mass re-issue is at the discretion of the local FMSS physical security office; eration should be given to loss rates and frequency of turnover. (
) Only authorized insignia approved by the Chief, FMSS are authorized for official wear. (
) Insignia designated for attachment to issued apparel must adhere to the set forth in IRM
, Publishing, Use of the Official IRS Seal, IRS Logo, Program Logos and Internal Logos. (

) Issuing Business Unit must safeguard insignia from unauthorized personnel. Business Unit may issue or transfer insignia to authorized personnel only. Business Unit is responsible for the recovery of insignia from unauthorized personnel and the destruction of damaged insignia. (

) All issued ID media must be recovered and returned to the local FMSS physical security office when employees or contractor employees: a. Request replacement ID media. b. Separate and terminate employment (resignation or retirement, ring to another federal agency, etc.). c. Are placed in non-work status. Note: Recovery of pocket commissions must follow procedures in IRM
, Physical Security Program, Civil Enforcement and Non-Enforcement Commissions. (

) All ID Media items must be recovered on the employee’s or contractor ee’s last workday prior to separating or terminating employment with IRS. manager and/or COR are responsible for initiating the process of recovering the ID Media items for separated employees/contractor employees. Every effort must be made to contact the separating employee or contractor employee and recover all ID Media items (including tracked letter, phone call, etc.) prior to ﬁling a SAMC and TIGTA report. The manager the COR must report all unrecovered ID Media items to SAMC and TIGTA. (

) The manager and/or COR are responsible for ensuring that all recovered ID Media is returned to the local FMSS physical security office no later than business day after the effective date of the separation with Form
, Document Transmittal, either in person or via mail. (
) The manager is required to use the HR Connect – SEC module to indicate Media recovery status as recovered or unrecoverable on the employee’s last Internal Revenue Manual
Physical Security Program, Civil Enforcement and Non-Enforcement Pocket Commissions. (

) All ID Media items must be recovered on the employee’s or contractor employ- ee’s last workday prior to separating or terminating employment with IRS. The manager and/or COR are responsible for initiating the process of recovering the ID Media items for separated employees/contractor employees. Every effort must be made to contact the separating employee or contractor employee and recover all ID Media items (including tracked letter, documented phone call, etc.) prior to ﬁling a SAMC and TIGTA report. The manager and/or the COR must report all unrecovered ID Media items to SAMC and TIGTA. (

) The manager and/or COR are responsible for ensuring that all recovered ID Media is returned to the local FMSS physical security office no later than one business day after the effective date of the separation with Form
, Document Transmittal, either in person or via mail. (
) The manager is required to use the HR Connect – SEC module to indicate ID Media recovery status as recovered or unrecoverable on the employee’s last
The manager is required to use the HR Connect – SEC module to indicate ID Media recovery status as recovered or unrecoverable on the employee’s last
10.2 Physical Security Program

workday. If the manager is unable to recover the ID media item(s), the manager must ﬁle a SAMC and TIGTA report, and update the SEC module to indicate the ID media as unrecoverable with a written explanation detailing the circumstances of non-recovery, including the SAMC and TIGTA (if available) report number. The SAMC and TIGTA reports must be completed prior to com- pleting the SEC module in HRConnect to include the SAMC and TIGTA, if available, information in the SEC module written explanation. The manager must provide SAMC and TIGTA, if available, report numbers to the local FMSS physical security office no later than one business day after effective date of separation via email or hard copy with Form 3210, Document Transmittal. The manager is responsible for the timely completion of all recovery and separation procedures.
Note: For additional guidance, see IRM
, Physical Security Program, Reporting. (
) The manager and/or COR is required to complete and submit Form

, Contractor Separation Checklist on the contractor employee’s last workday attach the checklist to the HRConnect- SCC module located on the Management Module (CMM). The manager or COR must indicate the status the ID media as recovered or unrecoverable on the Contractor Separation Checklist. When the manager or COR fails to recover the ID media, the manager or COR must complete a SAMC and TIGTA report and provide a written explanation detailing the circumstances of non-recovery, including the SAMC and TIGTA (if available) report numbers. The SAMC and TIGTA must be completed prior to completion of Form

, Contractor Separation Checklist. The manager or COR must provide SAMC and TIGTA (if available) report numbers to the local FMSS physical security office no later than one business day after effective date of separation via email or hard copy with Form
, Document Transmittal. The COR’s manager is responsible for the timely completion of all recovery and separation procedures. Note: For additional guidance, see IRM
, Physical Security Program, Reporting. (
) Employees and contractor employees should refer to IRM
, Penalties, for the penalties of failing to return ID media and/or the misuse ID Media. (

The local FMSS physical security office is responsible for verifying that a SAMC report has been completed for all unrecovered (lost, stolen, or compro- mised) ID media. The local FMSS physical security office must complete a SAMC report for all unrecovered ID media where the manager, COR, employee, or contractor employee has not completed the SAMC report. The local FMSS physical security office must annotate the SAMC report number Form 13716 or Form 13716-A, Part VI, Unrecoverable ID Media.

The local FMSS physical security office is responsible for verifying that a SAMC and TIGTA report has been completed for all unrecovered ID media separating employees. The local FMSS physical security office must a SAMC and TIGTA report for all unrecovered ID media no later than 30 days after separation where the manager, COR, or manager of the COR has not completed the SAMC and TIGTA report. The local FMSS physical security office must annotate the SAMC and TIGTA, if available, report numbers on Form 13716 or Form 13716-A, Part VI, Unrecoverable ID Media.
